article.title: Machine Learning Bell Nonlocality in Quantum Many-body Systems

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1(b) depicts a high-dimensional polytope representing classical correlations. What does the black line intersecting this polytope represent?
choices: A. A non-contextual hidden variable model
B. The boundary of entangled states
D. The maximum violation achievable by RBM

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, the authors compare the performance of their RBM-based method for detecting Bell nonlocality with which established numerical methods?
choices: A. Monte Carlo simulation and Tensor Networks
B. Exact Diagonalization and Density Matrix Renormalization Group
C. Support Vector Machines and Neural Networks
D. Quantum annealing and Variational Quantum Eigensolver

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the article, what is the key advantage of using RBMs for detecting Bell nonlocality in systems with all-to-all two-body correlators, as exemplified in the analysis of Ineq. (3)?
choices: A. RBMs can handle the permutation symmetry inherent in such inequalities, significantly reducing computational cost.
B. RBMs are more efficient than DMRG in finding the ground state energy of the corresponding Bell operator.
C. RBMs can accommodate random measurement settings for each party, going beyond the capabilities of permutation-invariant approaches.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (4) represents a Bell inequality with multipartite correlators. What is the significance of the finding that its maximal quantum violation, as determined by RBM, is always -2√2, irrespective of the system size?
choices: A. It suggests that the chosen RBM architecture is not powerful enough to capture the scaling of nonlocality with system size.
B. It highlights the computational efficiency of RBMs, demonstrating their ability to handle multipartite correlations for large systems.
C. It implies a connection to the Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt inequality, known to have a maximal quantum violation bounded by 2√2.
D. It indicates that multipartite Bell inequalities are not suitable for detecting many-body nonlocality in practical experiments.
